newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Rescued yachtsmen offer thanks for their lives.
newsitem.headline: Rescued yachtsmen offer thanks for their lives.

text.p: Rescued yachtsmen Tony Bullimore and Thierry Dubois arrived back on dry land to heroes' welcomes on Monday, giving thanks for their lives as thousands of well-wishers cheered and waved banners.
"It's absolutely astonishing," Briton Bullimore said after walking down the gangplank of the Australian navy frigate HMAS Adelaide at the Western Australian port of Fremantle.
"I'm slightly emotional about this but I'm going to turn around and say this 'thank you guys'," he said, raising his arms and pointing to the ship's crew at a dockside reception.

"Thank you Australia for giving me back my life," he said to a huge cheer from the crowd of about 5,000, including Australian Defence Minister Ian McLachlan who told the rescued sailors they owed their lives to the professionalism of Australia's military.
Frenchman Dubois also thanked the crew of the Adelaide and the Australian airforce crews who rescued them from freezing Antarctic seas on Thursday 1,400 miles south-west of Perth.
"I don't like a lot the word hero. We are not heroes. I think Australia have a lot of heroes on this ship and in the aircraft that saved us," Dubois said.
Bullimore and Dubois were competing in the Vendee Globe solo-handed round-the-world race.
The Adelaide was escorted into port by a flotilla of small craft as wellwishers on the dock waved British flags and sang along to the tune of Waltzing Matilda on a sunny morning.
Many people held up banners saying "Welcome Home Heroes".

Family members were ushered on board the frigate to greet Bullimore and Dubois privately, before they emerged for an official welcome, arm-in-arm and wearing grey naval uniforms with the name tags "Hon. 1" and "Hon. 2".
A smiling Bullimore was wearing a cap bearing the logo of an Australian TV channel which carried a live broadcast of the yachtmen's arrival.
The survival story of the 56-year-old former Royal Marine is expected to attract huge commercial interest from newspapers, television and movie studios.

Bullimore was picked up after surviving for four days in a dark air pocket in his upturned yacht, battered by Antarctic seas. His fate was unknown until he swam out from under his yacht and into the arms of rescuers.
Dubois, 29, was earlier plucked by helicopter from a tiny life-raft dropped by the Australian air force.
However, fears are held for another yachtsman in the race, Canadian Gerry Roufs, who has not been heard from since Tuesday.
A search for the Canadian, missing 2,500 miles from land between South America and the New Zealand, was suspended on Sunday.
Canadian authorities plan to use radar satellite photos to try to locate him.
Another race participant, Frenchman Raphael Dinelli, was rescued from his sinking yacht in the frigid seas south of Australia the day after Christmas.
Bullimore said he had been looked after like a baby during his time on the navy ship.
"I was getting embarassed being tucked in at night, 'Wanna cuppa tea, mate?', you know and all that, breakfast in the morning - I've never had it so good in all me life," he said.

Asked by one of the huge contingent of reporters on the dock how close he felt he had come to death, Bullimore said: "Just moments maybe, not hours ... the sea conditions were atrocious ... I really thought, 'Well I've bought me ticket this time ... I'm not going to come out of this time'," he said.
